Award.AwardTitle: Adaptive and Intelligent Forecast Engine Platform for Full-Spectrum Prediction of Solar Power Output

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop the concept of Smart Solar Farms. The approach is to integrate advanced solar forecasting methods into parallel computer platforms with the objective of quantifying the variability and availability of solar energy for power production, thus enabling solar integration with the power grid.

Intellectual Merit
This project integrates a very high number of inputs, varying from radiometric and meteorological time series to high-resolution remote sensing and ground-to-sky images, into a single adaptive and intelligent learning platform capable of local processing of high-fidelity forecasts. The proposed research is transformative in that novel, highly optimized natively parallel platforms will generate, in-situ, real-time forecasts for all time horizons of interest by a combination of machine learning software/hardware integration with intelligent energy management systems.

Broader Impacts
The reliable and economical integration of solar energy resources into the power grid is one of the most critical global technological challenges of our time. This project develops cost-effective tools that are essential to the integration of solar energy into a variety of possible smart grid solutions that aims at energy security and power quality improvements. We will also educate a new diverse generation of green energy experts, who master critical machine learning techniques specifically designed for variable resource power production and control. The concept of Smart Solar Farms will be demonstrated, and the test-bed will continue to provide high quality information, research opportunities and educational experiences for the community-at-large for many years beyond the duration of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reliable integration of solar energy resources into the power grid is one of the critical technological challenges of our time. In this project we developed methods and instruments that enable further integration of solar energy into a variety of smart grid solutions. We used different types of data, varying from radiometric and meteorological time series to high-resolution images to produce high fidelity solar forecasts. These data sets are ingested and processed into an adaptive and intelligent learning platform that is capable of processing forecasts for a wide range of time horizons.

During this project we tested several novel stochastic methodologies optimized to predict the solar resource and solar power generation for different forecast horizons: intra-hour (few minutes to 60 min in the future), intra-day  (few hours to 8 hours in the future) and day-ahead (24 hours to 48 hours in the future). The input data and forecast methodology strongly depends upon the forecast horizon. For instance, local sky images are paramount for intra-hour forecasts but are useless for day-ahead forecasts.

In this project we created new algorithms to extract information from sky images and produce intra-hour forecasts for the global (GHI) and the direct  (DNI) components of the solar resource. We also developed methods to estimate the prediction intervals for GHI and DNI since in general most forecast models published in the literature only provide point estimations without any probabilistic measure of the values certainty. Another problem addressed in this project was to create forecasting models specifically tailored for periods of large variability (or large ramps). This aspect of the research addresses another gap in many forecast models that are optimized for general weather conditions, ignoring the fact that problems in integrating solar resources into the power grid are almost exclusively related to periods of large variability (for example, a passing cloud causes DNI to drop to 0% and back to 100% in a matter of minutes).

For the intra-day and day-ahead forecasts we used satellite-derived GHI for the entire state of California to develop several GHI forecasting models. The study shows that the forecasting accuracy for GHI can be substantially increased through exogenous, satellite-derived data. We demonstrated how to select the best set of exogenous data from the available data, and demonstrated that the proposed methodology leverages the availability of low-cost satellite data in such a way that the forecasts can be improved for any point of interest. The last point is especially relevant considering the cost of high-quality ground-based sensors and their maintenance. Using the satellite-derived irradiance we also proposed data mining and data clustering tools to determine regions of coherent levels of solar resource labeled in terms of resource quality (where good quality means high irradiance at low variability). In this work we demonstrated that the knowledge of the regions of coherent GHI quality is very useful to the proper siting of solar farms. We contrasted this approach with the usual method that often relies in solar resource maps that only take into account the annual average irradiance.

Several of the forecast models developed in this project were implemented in Python and C++ and deployed in a stand-alone platform that can collect the irradiance data and produce the forecasts in real time. The stand-alone platform is based on the open source hardware single-board BeagleBone (BB) developed by Texas Instruments. BBs are credit-card-size single-board computers with the capability of desktop machines at the reduced cost of about $45 MSRP. The BB computer was augmented with additional hardware in order to add required functionalities (such as taking irradiance measurements and acquiring sky images simultaneously). ...
